body: It seems that the renderer process is referencing an object in the main process which has already been removed. It should be related to https://github.com/atom/electron/pull/4570, probably there is something wrong with my bookkeeping logic.

We're also getting this (probably same) issue, while calling win.setOverlayIcon(). Only happened after updating our Electron to latest master yesterday (previous version from a month or so ago didn't have this problem I think).

Uncaught Error: Cannot read property 'object' of undefined
TypeError: Cannot read property 'object' of undefined
    at ObjectsRegistry.get (Electron\resources\atom.asar\browser\lib\objects-registry.js:44:28)
    at EventEmitter.<anonymous> (Electron\resources\atom.asar\browser\lib\rpc-server.js:318:31)
    at emitMany (events.js:108:13)
    at EventEmitter.emit (events.js:182:7)
    at EventEmitter.<anonymous> (Electron\resources\atom.asar\browser\api\lib\web-contents.js:144:25)
    at emitTwo (events.js:87:13)
    at EventEmitter.emit (events.js:172:7)

This has broken `electron-connect`, and some of my own things.
Workaround: `remote.getCurrentWindow()` (or equivalent) every time that you need to do some remote work.

~~I doesn't appear to be due to #4570. There's a call to `objectsRegistry.remove()` which doesn't occur in previous version of `electron`~~

EDIT: This new call to `objectsRegistry.remove()` is _due to_ #4570.

Looking into this further, it appears that `0.36.10` and below work well, and `0.36.11` and greater are failing. It's peculiar that @CharlieHess is able to reproduce this with `0.36.9`!

Currently, when comparing `10` and `11`:
- With `10`, `remove()` is being called once on startup, and it's being applied to a `Menu` object
- With `11`, `remove()` is being called twice on startup: once for a `Menu`, and the other to a `BrowserWindow` object (_the_ `BrowserWindow` object0
- Following the code backwards, it looks like `v8Util` is calling the `destructor` for the `BrowserWindow` on `11`, but not `10`.

Unfortunately, I can't build `electron` prior to `v0.37.0` for some reason. I might need to figure out why that's not working before I can continue fixing this

Ah, I've figured out a sort-of symptom of the problem that I was having. There _is_ a difference between `0.36.10` and `0.36.11`, but it's based off of a bug that has existed for longer (e.g. `0.36.9` probably).

My issue was that `BrowserWindow` was being removed from `objects-registry`. In `0.36.10`, my application was the first to ever request a handle for the `BrowserWindow`. Electron would happily provide it, and life was good.

In `0.36.11`, [Electron needed to get `BrowserWindow` for its own purposes](https://github.com/atom/electron/compare/v0.36.10...v0.36.11#diff-be9eb62ca5c2374dd40c5e689111f99cR11). This _should_ be fine. This created an entry in the registry, so when my application requested the `BrowserWindow`, it would reuse the entry.
However, due to the **spooky bug**, the original entry becomes a null pointer, and a later reference to it kills everything in a fiery apocalypse of doom.

As for the bug itself:
I think that it's due to a race condition. I have a terrible, self-made log here:
(Note: `1` is the objects-registry id for `BrowserWindow`, and `5` is `Menu`. The others don't matter too much)
`::OnObjectGC()` and `::RunCallback()` are from `object_life_monitor.cc`
`add() and get()` are from `objects-registry.js`

```
// Electron commit 67db92d500632548466149770e4ae2cd7445999b
add:  1 // Electron getting BrowserWindow for figuring out visibility
get:  1
get:  1
::OnObjectGC() 1 // V8 marks pointer to BrowserWindow as garbage collected (?)
add:  2 // Other objects are added: functions, Menus, etc
add:  3
add:  4
get:  3
get:  2
add:  5
get:  5
get:  2
get:  3
add:  1 // Note that something else (my application) is now using `BrowserWindow`. Since the garbage-collect from earlier (see ::OnObjectGC) hasn't propagated to `object-registry`, things get in a bad state
get:  4
add:  1
get:  1 // This works for some reason, I think? Perhaps the actual garbage collection occurs around the same time as ::RunCallback()?
::OnObjectGC() 5
::RunCallback() 1
remove:  4 1
::RunCallback() 5
remove:  4 5

```

@zcbenz can I get your input on this? Maybe you can point me in the right direction? I think I've made some good progress, but I want to confirm my suspicions before I attempt a fix

I'm investigating #4570 some more, and it's confirmed to be the cause of the bug.
I've taken commit 67db92d500632548466149770e4ae2cd7445999b, but added `v0.36.8`'s `object-registry`, `rpc-server`, `remote.js` and `atom_api_v8_util.cc`. The illegitimate `OnObjectGC` is now gone.

I'm going to investigate to see which change in particular caused this

I've figured out why this race condition between `OnObjectGC()` and `RunCallback()` didn't matter before: the objects weren't GC'd. And the reason why they weren't GC'd is shown in the diff between `0.36.8` and`0.36.9`: https://github.com/atom/electron/compare/v0.36.8...v0.36.9#diff-674e27f5370ee910bd09f3c318aad8c8L262

Note that variables `moduleCache`, `builtinCache`, `windowCache`, etc. They acted as an additional cache layer, maintaining a reference and not allowing garbage collection to happen.

So, two solutions:
- Re-add these (gross) caches in `remote.js`, and cover up the symptom by ensuring no spooky garbage collects
- Handle garbage collection properly (my vote here).

Disclaimer: I _think_ I'm getting closer to solving this, but I might still be on the wrong path. I hope I'm almost there, though.

@mitchhentges Thanks for your investigation, it is extremely helpful here! I think the root cause is the callback of `setDestructor` (e.g. `RunCallback`) is called too late, so when a remote object is garbage collected and then referenced later, the `objectRegistry` would wrongly erase the reference.

I originally thought that, but upon further inspection, I'm not sure that that's the case.
1. It used to work before, even though `RunCallback` was called a lot later than `OnObjectGC`. If it worked before, then that can't be the cause of the bug
2. We're going to be dealing with passing a message between threads anyways (A delay between `OnObjectGC` and informing the renderer process). And if there's any delay at all, then there will be the potential for race conditions, and we'll have to handle it anyways

Note: my comment on [March 19th](https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/4733#issuecomment-198527938) was out of date for my PR. Perhaps I should've left one more comment showing my further investigation, and finding the clean way to handle reference count in `objects-registry`

> 1. It used to work before, even though RunCallback was called a lot later than OnObjectGC. If it worked before, then that can't be the cause of the bug

Before we introduced cache of remote objects in renderer process, every reference to remote objects in renderer process would increase the number of references in objectsRegistry, making this bug impossible to happen.

> 1. We're going to be dealing with passing a message between threads anyways (A delay between OnObjectGC and informing the renderer process). And if there's any delay at all, then there will be the potential for race conditions, and we'll have to handle it anyways

Renderer process is never informed, instead renderer process monitors the lifetime of remote object and informs the main process to increase/decrease references count, so there is no race condition happening.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8194131/14066778/c2b0b1c4-f485-11e5-8ec1-872914882078.png)

This bug still occurs on Electron 0.37.3
@KochiyaOcean That is unfortunate, can you make a reproducible example for it? The biggest trouble for me is I can not reproduce it on my machine.
Used to occur 100% of the time in our app; unfortunately I can't rebuild LCC anymore as of the last couple weeks, so I can't see whether this still triggers the case for us.
@zcbenz It seems that `remote.getCurrentWindow().webContents.on('dom-ready')` called on startup causes the crash. It happens twice on over 20 times of startup of my app.
@KochiyaOcean I'm unable to reproduce it by putting that code in a minimal app.
@zcbenz The reproduction of the bug is hard for me too... Maybe I should ask someone for helping my testing.

@zcbenz I've wrote a minimal app to reproduce the bug.
The repo is in https://github.com/KochiyaOcean/electron-remote-bug
Execute `Object.remoteClone(config.get('proxy'))` in the console will crash the app, but `Object.remoteCloneNoError(config.get('proxy'))` won't.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8194131/14198008/fdecd706-f807-11e5-8e0d-a15d4e9573d3.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8194131/14198027/43c0e984-f808-11e5-8e0d-be34c7c9f98e.png)
@KochiyaOcean It is perfect, clearly shows the problem, thanks!

```

  at EventEmitter.emit (events.js:185:7)
```

It seems that there is still some edge cases :disappointed:, @CharlieHess it would be great if you can work out a test case for it.

@zcbenz It's a non-trivial project to make a minimal example, since the Slack app is fairly complex and we only occasionally reproduce it. But most often we see this when creating new windows and doing remote code execution with `webContents.send`. I'll spend some time on an example this weekend.

We are getting this error occasionally still in 0.37.6.

```
TypeError: Cannot read property 'object' of undefined
    at ObjectsRegistry.get (…resources\electron.asar\browser\objects-registry.js:44:28)
    at EventEmitter.<anonymous> (…resources\electron.asar\browser\rpc-server.js:317:31)
    at emitMany (events.js:121:13)
    at EventEmitter.emit (events.js:195:7)
    at EventEmitter.<anonymous> (…resources\electron.asar\browser\api\web-contents.js:139:25)
    at emitTwo (events.js:100:13)
    at EventEmitter.emit (events.js:185:7)
```

The stacks are from OS X as well as Windows 8 and 10.

We are sending data to a new BrowserWindow. We have no idea how to reproduce this, we only have these stack traces from our users.

``` javascript
const win = new BrowserWindow({ width, height })
win.loadURL(url)
win.webContents.once('did-finish-load', function () {
  // Here:
  win.webContents.send('start')
})
```

@jankuca I see this when the underlying `BrowserWindow` has been killed.  In your case, might it be possible that between `did-finish-load` and sending to the inner web contents, that the window has been destroyed?  You might try checking for `win.isDestroyed` before dispatching.

I actually have a `closed` listener. I will try checking the `isDestroyed` property instead. 

``` javascript
var closed = false
win.once('closed', function () {
  closed = true
})
win.webContents.once('did-finish-load', function () {
  if (!closed) {
    win.webContents.send('start')
  }
})
```

---

When I try sending messages after the window is closed, i am getting the following error though.

``` javascript
win.webContents.once('did-finish-load', function () {
  win.once('close', function () {
    win.webContents.send('x')
  })
  win.destroy()
})
```

I have this error in 1.2.6 logged at random times into the chrome console.
@rchoudhary my app has `contextmenu` listener as well but no menu or clipboard. It's probably, caused by this listener.
@andruhon it's both actually. Removing the clipboard stuff isn't enough, removing the listener isn't enough. Removing both is the only solution for me. It's quite strange...
This is still happening in `1.3.0` for us, investigating more..

Another one here: https://github.com/zaggino/brackets-electron/issues/71
Seems like it's happening on Linux only
also happen for 1.2.8 in ubuntu x84. (but seems fine on x64, macOS, and Windows)

It's very strange. I built a markdown editor with electron. Suddenly the app can't render, save and so on. It happens under both Windows and Linux (didn't happen under macOS).

I wonder if it's something wrong in my code or electron's? If I am wrong, how can I found it?
For me it was Winston logging. If I delay the initial logging by a second (setTimeout) the rate of crashes reduces.
Perhaps we should re-open this issue. There are still cases where this error happens. @zcbenz

> Perhaps we should re-open this issue.

There is a newer issue, #7351, that is actively being investigated.
